title: For people with PhDs, what did you do after your thesis defense? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a story about one young PhD student in the lab where I was a secretary. Joe was considered by his professors and peers to be quite brilliant. At MIT, that's saying a lot. On top of that, he was in the jazz band, a good dancer, an Olympic-quality diver, and even good looking. His thesis defense was coming up in a couple of weeks, and he underwent a sudden major personality change. He went from cheerful and confident to morose, terrified, and despondent. All he would tell anyone was that his professional life was over: he would never pass his defense. That's it. His life was done. He packed up his desk and left the full box sitting on the floor by the door. Everyone, even his thesis supervisor, tried to tell him that it couldn't possibly be that bad, of course he'd pass, etc.etc. He was having none of it. The day of his defense he came in looking like hell. He was pale, haggard, unshaven, but ominously cheerful. Honestly, I'd rather he'd continued his depressed moping than this glittery, brittle cheer. It was scary. One of the other doctoral students asked him what was going on. Joe told him quietly that it was simple, everything was very simple. There was no longer any need for worry. He'd go in, do his defense, fail, and leave. He'd arranged for someone to sublet his room, sold off or given away his few possessions, and packed what remained into his car. Hadn't called his parents yet--they’d find out soon enough. He was called into the little conference room next door to face the four professors who would determine his fate. We were all staring at each other. The office was silent. Then his girlfriend, a lovely girl who we all expected he'd marry, came charging in, wild-eyed, demanding to know where Joe was. We all just looked in the direction of the conference room. She burst into tears and said he'd left a very brief message on her answering machine, breaking up with her. She tried to call him but his home phone was now disconnected. Yow. After a couple of hours, Joe returned to his desk. Didn't say a word or acknowledge anyone: he just closed his office door behind him. I shamelessly manufactured an errand that would take me past the conference room where the committee was deliberating, hoping to glean some clue as to the outcome. They had opened the door a bit and as I (very slowly) passed, I heard snippets of conversation from within. “…don't know why he was so worried…brilliant defense…best I've seen in years…post-doc grant…” So I rapidly tip-toed (which is a major trick, if you've never tried it) back to the office and whispered to the guys that he'd passed. A very muted roar went up, and I got volundrafted to tell Joe. Tapped on the door. No response. Rang his phone. Ditto. Gently opened the door and whispered, “Joe. Joe! You passed.” In a vicious hiss I had not suspected he could produce, he snarled back, “That's NOT funny!” My phone rang: it was his thesis supervisor calling from next door. Joe wasn't answering his phone and he wanted me to track Joe down and produce him posthaste. It took most of us to almost physically haul Joe next door, shove him in the room, and slam the door. I again got volundrafted, this time to set up reservations for a last-minute party which was specified to include large quantities of alcohol. One of the guys made a brief and cryptic phone call, took up a hasty hushed collection, and disappeared to, um, meet someone. Another guy took off to find and retrieve the girlfriend. A bewildered but much happier Joe was ushered back into the office by his thesis advisor. I had pulled off one of my famous short-notice logistical miracles and found them a function room at a favorite nearby Chinese restaurant--that wasn't the miracle--and found a couple of limos willing to take 20 potentially drunk, stoned, and rowdy young men to the restaurant, then deliver them to their respective homes at a presumably very late hour. These limos were to materialize outside our building within 20 minutes. They did. That was Joe's post-defense party, which I actually didn't attend. On their way out the door, both of the professors rattled off a list of phone calls expected and to be made, appointments to be rescheduled (yeah, way ahead of you there. Already done.), and a few other tasks I could do since the office would be quiet that afternoon.

Tuesday, April the 24th, 2001 3:30 pm: I am sitting in the Visual Perception and Cognition Lab located on the 4th floor of the Graduate Faculty building. I cannot keep my mind focused on much. I’m nervous. I’m hoping that the members of my committee had a good day and that no one is seeking to displace their anger onto me, or more accurately, my notoriously difficult Committee Chair. I purposely chose the most masochistic route possible in an unnecessary attempt to prove that I was not mediocre. My Dissertation Committee is no different - three of them are the brightest minds in the Department. The 4th committee member is a required “outside” member known to be both kind and brilliant. I’m hopeful that her presence will keep the other three in line. 3:45 pm: I make my way to the designated classroom on the south side of the 2nd floor. No one is there yet. I’m hoping they remember today is the day. I’ve brought drinks and snacks that I’ve chosen specially for each of the committee members - 2 male senior professors and 2 female senior professors. My defense is scheduled to start at 4:00 pm. I begin nervously checking and then double-checking the computer/projector connection. 4:10 pm: Everyone is in the room. No one seems to be paying attention to me. I’m nervous. My ears are ringing. My committee chair suggests we begin. 5:10 pm: I’m done. I’ve answered all the questions they had for me, and I am now politely asked to leave the room. I believe they are discussing me and my work. I’ve been studying the cognitive sciences (attention, memory, perception, emotion, consciousness, thought, information processing) for 6+ years in this dark, brutalist building under some of the greatest minds of their generation. But this is more of a surreal moment, disconnected from everything of which I am familiar. I am not sure what I am supposed to do out here in the hallway, by myself, in this space. I observe students heading to their classes. I look for a familiar face, but this is not a floor generally used by the psychology department, and I see no one I know. I feel lonely in this experience. I am too energized to sit still yet surprisingly also sad. Is this what postpartum depression feels like? I wonder how long they will continue to deliberate. Among all the times I thought about completing my Ph.D., I never once thought about standing outside a room, by myself, waiting AFTER the defense for a determination of my academic worth. I should have prepared myself for this moment. Why is this taking so long? 5:18 pm: One of the male members of my Dissertation Committee opens the door and asks me to come back into the room. He puts his arm around me to usher me in and whispers as I pass him, “Congratulations, Doctor.” I realize he wants to be the first to congratulate me and it’s a nice feeling - not the “Doctor” part but that he wanted to usher me back into the room. He is a brilliant academic who taught my first Cognitive Science course. He is also Chair of the Psychology Department. 5:18–5:30 pm: Lots of claps and congratulations. Hugs. Handshakes. Someone has brought alcohol to toast the event. I’m all smiles - but I think I’m more happy to be back in the room. There is a purpose here. We begin discussing my upcoming postdoctoral position in July where I will be continuing my work on Change blindness. I thank each of them in the formal “Doctor” manner - they are still the real Doctors in the room. 5:45–6:30 pm: I’ve packed up the room. I bring everything usable back up to the lab. I sit down at my desk, call my wife and tell her the news. She congratulates me and I confirm that I’ll be coming to dinner. Before I had left for school that morning I told her if I didn’t pass, I wasn’t going to be interested in a night out. I then call my parents and thank them for all their support. I remind them how there was a time when they didn’t think I was going to graduate high school. I then sit for a little bit, all the other lab members are now in class. I say a prayer of gratitude. I get up, turn off the lights and lock the door behind me. I know I’m coming back in the following morning because we are preparing for an upcoming conference presentation in Sarasota, Florida. However, I decide that I won’t come in any earlier than 12:00. 6:30 pm: I now leave the Social Research building for the first time as a Ph.D, although it doesn’t feel any different. I expected somehow to walk taller and to be more confident. I say to myself, “You have a Ph.D., You’re a Doctor” but I don’t feel the way I thought I would. In a strange way I actually feel less confident in my knowledge. Repeating in my head, “I’m a Doctor” rings fraudulent. This makes no sense to me. Maybe I’ll feel more confident after the formal graduation ceremony in May? I hope so. I think about this as I walk to the downtown train. 7:00 pm: My wife has made a reservation at an Italian restaurant (Ecco) which is downtown. I walk in and see her with a very close friend and his wife (who was also a friend before they were married). They congratulate me with hugs and a waiting bottle of wine. We toast. My wife then hands me a box with newly printed business cards that read: Michael E. Silverman, Ph.D.

My Defense was scheduled for 2 pm. I came into work nice and late, and took time to set up everything in the room. The all-important food (barbecue for the guests and animal crackers for my adviser) were laid out on a table. A minute after the appointed time, I was introduced and began my talk. My presentation was almost exactly one hour, the appropriate duration, and I felt awful. From the beginning, I was beset with a number of minor stumbles, and I never really felt like I hit my presentation stride. While I didn’t think I was in danger of failing (I had a lot of worthy content), it didn’t feel good to wrap up my time at Florida State in mediocre fashion. I received a couple of polite questions from the room and none from my family or coworkers (thankfully…I made that mistake once with a colleague, and he never forgave me). I handled these well, and then my committee dismissed my guests. My excellent crowd kindly liberated my spread of food from the conference room, and vanished, save for family and a couple close friends who remained in the hallway outside. My committee asked me questions for about half an hour. These questions ranged from regarding my presentation, to the deeply technical regarding my research. Some asked me to explain phenomena, while others asked me to extrapolate and make a prediction of where the work could go. The most important question, “So where do you go from here?” had a satisfactory answer - I had a postdoctoral research position lined up across the country in a famous lab - and I knew the decision was made. I was dismissed. I went outside the conference room, met with my friends and family, and sat down. They reassured me that my presentation wasn’t all that bad, despite my repeated and earnest misgivings. Hugs were had, photos were taken, and I awaited the news with all the patience of a child on Christmas. Ten minutes later, the door opened and my boss Tom came around the corner. Those wonderful words, “Congratulations, Doctor,” were the first he said, a great grin on his face. My formal education, one that began in childhood was over. I was no longer a student, but a Doctor of Nuclear Chemistry. After a few more hugs and tears, I went back into the conference room, and shook hands with everyone on the committee. I was given a number of changes to my dissertation, and a deadline of a week, but I decided I could wait a day to address them. A quick message to my colleagues brought another half-dozen people down to scavenge what food remained and share apple cider, while I reveled in the moment. The first chance I got to sit down and alert the internet of my news, I took a picture to immortalize the moment (see below). It was a bit like getting married, where everything was special, and there were happy faces all around - and like getting married, it’s expected to be “till death do you part.” We packed up the rest of the food, then my wife chauffeured me back home. We relaxed, joked around, and I played some Star Wars Battlefront II to relax. That evening, we met my boss at the fanciest restaurant in town, and had a lovely dinner with my parents. As the day ended, I knew - it was worthwhile. Despite all the hard times and long days and stresses and questions and sleepless nights and anxiety and work and uncertainties and … It was all justified, that day. But wait, there’s more. The very next day, I was able to use my shiny new degree and spend my last week in town working on a new substance that a collaborator had produced. (Edit: That substance has now been published in Scientific Reports - Superconductivity in a uranium containing high entropy alloy!) Seven days later, I was boarding a plane, so I had to work quickly! But it was all taken care of in due time, and now we have another paper or two pending! Not all is relaxation afterwards, unfortunately, but busy and productive is better than busy and unproductive, and I am very much enjoying my new job!

I got my PhD in the UK where your final defence is called Viva. It is a pivoting moment, as not everybody passed their Viva. Instead of a committee you have an internal and an external examiner, they alone decide if you pass. The Viva is closed, meaning the only people attending are you (the terrified candidate), the examiners and if you want to, your supervisors (that is advidsors for our US audience, and yes you have two if them, to make life harder). Your supervisors can't not say anything during the Viva, they get to observe and take notes. You usually know the internal examiner, they have been the examiner for your previous milestones, such as the 9 month and transfer Viva (milestones may vary between institutions). In most cases you will never have met your external examiner before. Here comes the kicker, in the UK most people are only funded for 3 years, after this you are expected to live on knowledge and air alone. However, the combination of the fact that doing a PhD in three years is extremely difficult and that landlords seldom accept air as payment means that sooner or later people must have their Viva. This usually happens in the 4th year. Thus, not everybody passes. I know somebody who went in for the PhD Viva and came out with an additional Master degree. What is more common is that the Viva may take 5 hours, of the student being grilled by the examiners and then being told to spend months improving their thesis. In the middle the examiners break for lunch and eat at the fanciest place on campus, the candidate is usually too stressed to eat at all. So on the day of my Viva I woke up super early as my parents texted me to wish me good luck. Prior to smartphones, I didn't turn of the sound as nobody would text or call in the middle of the night anyway (strange times). I then wore a T-shirt walking in as I was thinking I would sweat a lot walking in the sunshine. It was the 13th of June, the very last day to have your Viva if you wanted to make that years graduation ceremony. Once in the office I changed in the toilet (British English, for restroom), that specific smell or detergent, soap and nerves is something I'll never forget (building was brand new, not all toilets in the UK smell clean). My Viva started at 10 am with me giving a 10 minute presentation of my research. Then the questions begun, and after 10 minutes of questions I knew I had passed. I knew because none of the questions were difficult, and even though it went on for a total of just shy of 2 hours, it never because difficult. Afterwards one of my supervisors ran back to his office to email the entire research group (department for US readers) to let them knew I had passed. After a lunch of a not so tasty pub sandwich in the cafeteria I headed to the pub to meet my friend who had her Viva the same morning (remember it was the last day to make summer graduation). Only a few people thought it a good idea to start drinking at 1 pm, luckily one of them had made a cake to celebrate. However, soon the pub was full, after all the official start of drinking is 4pm on a normal Friday and it is not every day you have dual Vivasto celebrate. Strangely enough, even though my memory is crystal clear when it comes to the morning, I can't really remember much of the evening.

Immediately after my dissertation defense, I had a sense of relief that the last 7 years of my life hadn’t been wasted. Then my parents and my girlfriend went out to eat, and I slept well that night. The following couple of days were more difficult. I had this nagging feeling of dissatisfaction. I had mentally built this moment up in my head as a critical threshold and things would fall into place afterward. I wasn’t delusional, I just had to keep telling myself that it would be worth it, to push through the self-doubt, rejection, and anxiety all those years. However, reality didn’t meet expectations, as it seldom does. I also couldn’t believe it was real. I kept expecting the university administrator to email that I had missed some critical document or review and that I wasn’t able to graduate. Over the next six months, life really broke me down. I graduated in 2013, during the “fiscal cliff”, and the American government was shut down. There were no jobs to be had for a space physicist. I was frustrated, and angry. I felt like my effort had been wasted by a bunch of short sighted politicians, and I’d wind up working whatever shit job I could get. Eventually I landed a post-doc and things were better, but those months after graduation really robbed me of my confidence. It’s been 7 years since I graduated and things have improved a great deal. I work as a data scientist, and my work is valued. I make a reasonable salary. I even get the occasional head hunter trying to recruit me, which goes a long way to restore my confidence and remind that getting my PhD wasn’t a total waste of my time.

Ah the sweet sweet day. I defended my PhD two years ago. I was absolutely looking forward to my thesis defense. I had two red bulls with me to get me through the long day I expected to have. I defended in the morning with very minimal revisions to my thesis. My thesis committee congratulated me. It was all over by noon. I didn’t even open my energy drinks. I was really excited, but also had an empty feeling in my stomach. I felt uneasy. I didn't want to eat or drink. The thing I had worked so hard for, had been looking forward to for so long was suddenly over and I didn't know how to deal with it. My family in India was awake until I was done with my defense and called me to congratulate. My aunt and boyfriend (now husband) took me out shopping immediately after and bought me really nice stuff and some ice cream; they were so proud of me! Later in the evening my PhD advisor had a small party at his home to celebrate my defense. Towards the end of the party I was so wiped out from having used my so much of my mental energy that I couldn't talk. I just needed to go home and sleep. I went home, oiled my hair, and went to bed. But I couldn't sleep all night. I kept replaying the entire defense in my head over and over again and kept tossing and turning the whole night. I went back to work the very next day and was congratulated by colleagues, professors and friends. Some of them had follow up questions about specific results and experiments that I had presented in my defense. It took me a good couple of days for the feeling to sink in. A week later I had a nice night with cocktails with some of my friends to celebrate my defense. Fun night! A week after that my then boyfriend took me on a trip to Cuba to celebrate my defense. We got engaged on that trip, in Cuba. It took me about a year to be proud of having earned my PhD. I kept downplaying it, so much so that I didn't make an effort to go to my own graduation which happened six months after my defense. I truly believed that I had done a good job by fluke for a while there. Imposter syndrome is real y'all! I had been offered a job before I defended my thesis that I was beyond excited to start. It's the kind of job that I had hoped for and dreamed about! The next two weeks were just me packing and preparing to move out of the country to start my new job in a totally different country. The weeks before I left also involved telling a lot of people that yes, I am REALLY moving to Vietnam from the USA by myself :) Here's a picture of the cake from my defense party

Some context to my answer—I had already been working in industry for a year, and came to Georgia Tech only for a week to defend my thesis and meet old friends and mentors. I interned only once all my PhD research was done, so this made the academia to industry transition very smooth. After I was congratulated and told I passed by the committee, I went out to lunch with my adviser. It’s a tradition of sorts in our group—the adviser drives the student for lunch after the defense. It was a great conversation, and we could talk more openly and broadly now. I had grown wiser in that year, and had new things to share, and I could now understand more of what my adviser meant when he spoke about deep topics. I had a better grasp of the context behind his statements. Definitely a step up in our intellectual relationship. I then spent the evening walking around Atlanta, revisiting some of my favorite areas, and went for dinner to a fancy restaurant that I used to love going to alone. Then I visited a few of my closest friends in graduate school, and we wound up talking from 9pm to 7am. The discussion had 4 participants, all PhD students—one civil engineer, one astrophysicist, one working on educational technology for teaching STEM, and an electrical engineer (me). Given the diverse audience, the discussions ranged from physics, to philosophy, to psychology etc. It was exhilarating. Overall, the day of my defense was great. Everything went according to plan or exceeded expectations. The entire week in Atlanta was a very enjoyable social event for me.

I was in Boston and my family stayed behind in Ohio. I flew out to put on final preparations and meet with my supervisor for my defense presentation review. We identified a few things that I cleaned up in preparation for the defense a couple days later. In the defense, everything went smoothly. When it was questioning time, one of my committee members asked a question that my supervisor and I had not discussed the possibility of being asked. I caught his eye and I saw a flash of concern and worry. He was wondering what I was going to say. I responded, “I was wondering the same thing last night. ‘How would this method apply to other parts of the development process?’” I then flipped to the next slide which had a detailed map of the development process and about 10 red circles where my methodology could be applied. My supervisor sported a look of incredulity. “I see many places on the development process where I think it would work and I will have the opportunity to test some of them in my current job.” The committee member laughed and thanked me. The committee then asked me to leave the room for deliberations. When I returned, they congratulated and greeted the newly minted “Dr. Long.” My supervisor came up and asked me where that chart came from and why I though to develop it the night before. “I don’t know, but it seemed important last night.” As we were transitioning into the reception room, I paused and updated my Facebook status, “I am now married to a Doctor’s Wife.” The department admin person told me I’d better CALL my wife and let her know. I did. The reception went on for a while. Then my thesis supervisor took the remaining members of my PhD lab cohort to a very expensive restaurant and picked up the tab for dinner and wine. The next day I cleaned up as much of the thesis document as I could. Some of it would need to be finished at home. The following day, I got on an airplane to go home to my family in Ohio. Then, I started catching up on the sleep I’d missed in the last 3.5 years….

I did make a diary entry on that day, and here it is, with some minor edits: Nobody talks about what one does the morning of one’s Ph.D defence. In my case it was, after a run-through and fix-ups, pacing. Writing a poem riff on the caption to the photo of the green tea white chocolate mousse I made the previous evening: I was going to work on my dissertation defence I made green tea white chocolate mousse instead it took a lot less time even if you hand whip the cream and get the folding right of course the mousse was a final draft the dissertation would still have questions revisions committee discussion all the things i already know i did wrong when all i did possibly wrong here was not add sugar and it didn't matter it was sweet enough the audience perked up immediately on mention of mousse with a brightness they somehow lacked on mention of hearing my rehearsal again it needs no defending of its right to be this mousse of matcha and ganache the colour of celadon and smooth lightness that defies solidity many friends will say that they will wolf it down this does not happen with dissertations because of unreportable sadnesses i decided to settle that evening for a responsive eatership even if the schedule is set the day the hour to proceed through a different ceremony without ganache. (Pastiche of, of course, The Poet's Occasional Alternative Poem by Grace Paley - Poem Hunter .) Going out just to take a walk with the excuse that I wanted to restock Excedrin. I was out, and even though I have very little evidence it works for me, one thing I was very afraid would happen before my defence was a migraine or migraine aura. I thought I would still go through with the presentation even if half my body was going numb or I could not know where my hand was — but not knowing words would be another matter. At one point I was telling N— a dissertation defence situation and I got stuck on the word for the person giving the defence. “The—the—victim! Why can’t I remember the word? The candidate, that’s it!” Later, laughing about it, N— suggested, “the defendant.” Eating. Pacing. At 2 pm, heading with N— to campus. “A student’s performance may receive a failing grade for any of the following reasons: - Textual inaccuracies - Lack of stylistic awareness - Repeated interruptions of the continuity - Substantial omissions - Complete breakdown of the performance” Those are in the guidelines for the Royal Conservatory’s ARCT exam, and I joked that although CK would not recommend I defend if he was not sure that I would pass, would be willing to fight for me to pass — but complete breakdown of the performance was still an option. And as it is listed, it must have happened. As N— and I walked to campus, I recalled the scene in Robertson Davies’s The Lyre of Orpheus where the dissertation project of nineteen-year-old socially maladjusted composing prodigy Hulda “Schnak” Schnakenburg, completing E.T.A. Hoffmann’s opera about King Arthur, is finally being staged — and she overhears that the producer she had fallen in love with speaks of her disparagingly, she tries to commit suicide and is rushed to hospital. “The vote was six for acceptance of the degree, Professor Pfeiffer abstaining, and the Dean forgoing his privilege of casting a vote. The examination was over, and Schnak, dead or alive, was therewith a Doctor of Music.” (Spoiler alert: she lives.) It was when entering the quad that I stopped and pulled the beta blockers out. I had half an hour before my defence, which is almost exactly propranolol’s activation time. I dry-swallowed two. I’m glad I did. I was angsting with nervousness as I set up N— and me in the conference room and went to the office to borrow a dongle to connect my computer. Itamar saw me. “I hear you’re giving a talk today?” he joked. “Yeah, it’s a talk,” I said. “It’s a workshop! And I’m bored of my topic, so I’m doing it on nineteenth century ballet instead.” Yimei came by, and I introduced N— to her as, “This is Yimei, she’s a postdoc?” “A visiting scholar here,” she said. “And this is N—, who is—“ “I’m her support,” he said. “I go around with him rather a lot and tell him what I think of him,” I paraphrased Douglas Adams. It was twenty minutes to, so I decided I had the time and the need for a chocolate run. I asked Yimei or N— to watch my stuff for me, and said I would go to the Pret, but ended up going to the Divinity School coffee shop and grabbing two Chocolove bars, one of dark chocolate with cherries and one of dark chocolate with raspberries, as I couldn’t decide which one, and embraced the power of And. When I returned and opened the Macbook again, the screen had done that thing where it shifts to the other desktop — in fact, to a desktop background that I had not used in over a year but which had been my default at the time I transferred my data from my previous Macbook Pro. So it took N— a bit of time to fiddle with talking the Displays preferences into displaying again. And the room filled up. Kate, with cookies, and Anais on her phone Skyping in to see my defence. My committee. Ming. Lenore. Adam, Kay, Robert, Julian, Amara, Yimei, Tab, Woody, Ksenia, Saule and her husband — even James came, and took a seat at the table, looking a little awkward for his size and him an astrophysicist among the linguists. Anubav was the dean’s rep, which was a good thing (CK had asked for him, as someone who I had talked to and who would be sympathetic). Jerry. Patrick, of course. It was perhaps the most attended defence the little conference room of Rosenwald 208 had seen. The beta blockers were keeping me then from feeling much of anything. As I write this, I feel a lump in my throat. I am loved. I didn’t realize how much I am loved. I gave my talk. It worked out, to my surprise, to exactly thirty minutes. In the rehearsal, I thought it was going to be over 35 minutes. People laughed a few times at the right places. Kay had to sneak out during the questions, whispering support to me. Then came the questions. Malte asked me the hardest question that my model doesn’t really address, which is why moral statements do not have an acquaintance inference. That drove most of the discussion, although when the floor was opened up, Patrick also opened up the idea that I may be throwing out babies with the bathwater (my words, not his) in claiming that built-in Experiencer roles do not play a part. Then we were asked to step out. There in the hallway, I mostly talked to James and N—. James enjoyed the talk. He and N— had briefly seen each other before, but had not talked much. Kate and Anais were happy to congratulate me. Kate had left her box of cookies in the room. I gave my joke that when the committee takes a long time to vote, they are actually deciding where to have dinner. James remarked that at astrophysics defences, the audience is sent out for the question period as well, rather than having the question period public as we do in linguistics. Then — it seemed a short time — CK came out and shook my hand. I hugged N— tightly. James congratulated me and said that he had a draft that he’d promised his advisor this afternoon, so he had to go. I would later see that in our team’s group he had posted, “Congratulations, Doctor Vardo,” and about ten people chimed in with congratulations. CK brought me back in to show me the approval sheet, and said he would check off the “Approved with minor revisions”; he had been of the opinion that there would not be any needed revisions, but I myself might want a few. The other options were “Approved with no revisions”, “Approved with major revisions,” and “Not approved,” I think. The committee had signed off on it. I had until the Spring quarter to file it if I wanted to graduate then. I asked Kate to take a few pictures, since I knew she had the artistic capabilities. Her cookies were beautiful icing swirls of various colours on shortbread; I took a picture of those too. Itamar had to get called back in to have the entire committee be there. CK said we will be going for drinks at the A10. The people coming with us would end up being CK, Malte, N—, Patrick, Woody and Kate. And I did open my Macbook and type the Facebook status I had known I would type for this occasion since I got Facebook: Tamara Vardo , Ph.D Linguistics. Kate and Woody raced each other to be the first ones to Love it, and tied. We were found seats in the A10 at a central table in their bar area. I told CK about the last time N— and I had eaten there, the evening after we finished my move. CK said the first round of drinks was on him, and also ordered the frites. They have a delightful dill aioli dip for them that I liked. I ordered a glass of Bordeaux after consulting with our server as to what it was like, and she said it was a very full-bodied red, a mix of cabernet sauvignon and merlot grapes, rather tannin-heavy. And indeed it was. I enjoyed it. N— had a Safe Word, a cocktail with a mix of absinthe, that I tried and found interesting. I hadn’t noticed the Negroni on the cocktail list. And it kind of felt more appropriate to toast my own defence with wine. Mostly, Patrick and CK talked about how to improve the Semantics and Philosophy Workshop and whether it was feasible to reform it, or to have something like a collaborative semantics project that is like a reading group, but with the result being a paper. Once they were done the drinks, CK, Malte and Patrick left. I offered to N— that we stay for dinner; he had been about to suggest the same. Woody and Kate would stay with us. So we ordered more frites, and N— and I shared the striploin steak. Woody and Kate had salads. Finally, N— settled the bill, and we called it an evening, and I thanked Kate and Woody very much for showing up. We returned home and I lay on the bed for a while, just processing. Then we went to catch the late showing of “Any Number Can Win,” with Alain Delon and Jean Gabin. It is an interesting film for the subtitles that tried to convey the register of French they were speaking in, by using words like “gonna” and “ya.” It is also interesting for its multiple titles — billed as “Any Number Can Win,” the subtitles had the title “The Caper That Sank,” and the actual French title is “Mélodie en sous-sol,” which literally means “A melody from the basement,” which was how the film’s title was translated into Russian, and it is based on the novel “The Big Grab.” At 11 or so, we returned home, and got the shower running. While we were showering, I felt queasy. And had to step out. And so while N— was still in the shower, I summarily upchucked into the toilet pretty much all of my defence celebration dinner. I don’t know if I will ever know if that was my excess sensitivity to food poisoning — N— had no reaction whatsoever — or just the cortisol leaving my system, as my friend M— speculated. I didn’t have a headache, as food poisoning often manifests itself. And that, for my own future, was how I defended my doctoral dissertation.

I partied hard for a few days and was proud of being a Dr. I thought of the teacher who told I was stupid and will be a failure and shed a tear. I wrote my name with Dr...wherever I traveled on flights. The euphoria lasted a few days and eventually evaporated like water on a hot pan. If we are not genuinely happy and balanced inside, a Ferrari or 2 million dollars is not going to change it. I hated school life and was always called a 'stupid boy' in school. The teachers used to beat me a lot and everyone called me a stupid boy. I had some severe learning disabilities and no one knew. I didn't know it too. They thought I was just lazy and careless. I didn't want to be stupid and that's what pushed me further and further to study more. Eventually the phd was finished. And it was a good success. Few Nature papers and two Nobel laureate supervisors. I sat in my room thinking of the vast emptiness that had suddenly engulfed me after the high had worn off. I had no idea what was next. What was I chasing and what excited me, no no..shhh…I need some silence. I decided not to do anything work related and decided to travel with the little money I had. I won't say it opened my eyes like many do. It didn't open anything. I disliked traveling alone and got bored. I saw nobody really cares about anyone and we are just a speck in this vast world. People have their own problems and are so preoccupied with their affairs. Unless you add value to their life, nobody will look at you. People liked if you talk about them and listen to them and sympathize with them, but would not have the heart to hear how you feel. Anyway, I traveled for one year and visited several countries backpacking. I returned to my scientific work and joined a postdoc. I didn't understand the world. Somewhere deep inside, I'm still the same stupid boy.

I did my PhD in chemical and biomolecular engineering. My student visa did not expire immediately after the thesis was passed 4 months after submission - I was allowed to travel in and out of Australia on that visa, as well as work if I wanted to. After the thesis was passed, I had 10 months left on the visa. I set my graduation date for Melbourne’s winter, where I could dress up nicely in a suit (and not sweat like crazy over it, unlike graduation ceremonies in summer), which was 2 months before the visa was set to expire. I went out on a YOLO limb and decided to play Uber driving. Working specific strategic hours to capitalise on surge demand and maximise the surge dollars, aided by more experienced surge chasers that I met on an online forum. The strategising was amazing, I must say, especially to my INTJ brain. The hacks that were employed to make use of the system in an “appropriate” way that wouldn’t get us deactivated was absolutely key. It gave me an insight into running a business and how to stay afloat/at least survive for the period that I wasn’t getting any funding after thesis submission. When another opportunity for business developing came along, I jumped on it. The idea of being able to run with my own income, do business in other countries without physically being in those countries (do check out my Instagram Dr Joel Yong (@thethinkingscientist) • Instagram photos and videos for more information), and most importantly - because the sales of products anywhere around the world earn me points that are converted into the currency of my home business distributor account (Singapore), I didn’t have to deal with having to set up overseas bank accounts or income taxes from those countries where sales were conducted - I only have to deal with income taxes from my home country. Having a background in biomolecular engineering helps me to understand how the biochemistry mechanisms in our body works, and how different vitamins and minerals aid or inhibit those mechanisms. Having a PhD in that area helps me to sift through the research in that area and determine what marketing claims are credible and what claims are nonsensical, then presenting that information and recommending quality products nets me the business income. Otherwise, the majority alternative would be to become a lowly paid postdoctoral researcher, fighting like mad to get an assistant professorship, and fighting like mad again to obtain tenure. Rat racing under the mantra of “publish or perish”? I don’t really like working with that mentality. What I do like, though, is being able to learn what I like learning about. Understanding various mechanisms and how things work in the body. Raising awareness about how Type 2 diabetes ain’t just a sugar intake problem, as such: Dr Joel Yong on Instagram: “Each of our bodies comprises trillions of live cells. These cells have a whole lot of functions in our body, which are dependent on the…” Or how weight loss depends on how well the liver is operating, and not just about calorie restriction or the fad “keto diet”. Especially when I heard about a friend’s friend snacking on butter sticks because of some “keto diet” recommendation. Like dude, processed food?! Really?! Dr Joel Yong on Instagram: “The #keto #diet eh? Another #fad, or what? So many people profess to be following it, without even knowing why they’re doing what they’re…” I do want people to know why they’re doing what they’re doing, and not just because some random social media influencer said so. That’s a big problem with society these days. A little knowledge is a dangerous thing. Like butter sticks in a “keto diet”.

I defended my thesis two years ago. One of my committee members claimed that I had copied ideas from his student's thesis without giving him due credit. As a result I did not pass the defense. I tried to talk to him and prove to him that I had not borrowed or copied anything. But he decided to clear me only after a phone call with his student. After that my advisor did take me and my friends to dinner to celebrate even though I hadn't technically cleared the defense. I lied to my family and friends that I had cleared my thesis, but I could hardly sleep for days following that. What followed was several days of intense stress and gathering evidence to prove my innocence to that committee member. Eventually we spoke to his student and cleared that my ideas were original. The committee member even apologized for the inconvenience and said it was a big misunderstanding. It would take another three weeks before he would actually sign the documents, because he wasn't happy with several aspects of my thesis document and wanted me to run more experiments. I must mention that at one point during this whole ordeal I was so frustrated that I hit myself on my head with my phone till the screen cracked. Eventually when the signatures came and i was officially done, I felt like nothing. I did not feel relieved, I did not feel happy, I did not feel angry, I did not feel thankful. I felt numb. And after a few days I had other problems to deal with, which I shall write about in another post in the future.

My viva exam was a bit of an ordeal. I did the PhD at King’s College, London, but was teaching in Breda, the Netherlands. This necessitated a flight to London whenever in-person meetings were required, such as the viva. In addition to the travel requirement, I was scheduled for hernia surgery a few days after the viva. Even worse, the night before, I had experienced such severe pain through the right side of my body that I had to go to hospital. The doctor gave me a pain killer that knocked me out completely. When I regained consciousness at about midnight, the doctor told me I was in no condition to travel to London for my viva exam. I was determined to go. It had taken a lot of time to get the thesis through all the stages required to get to the point where the viva could be held. Scheduling the viva on its own took several months. I did not want to create a potential delay of another several months. I asked for some pain killers and left the hospital. A few hours later, at about six in the morning, I began my journey. A cab to the train station, a train to Schipol airport, a plane to Heathrow, a train to Waterloo station, a walk to my hotel where I checked in, then another walk down to the Maxwell building a few blocks away. I arrived about a half hour early. By the time I sat down, I had a splitting headache. It was so bad that I could barely concentrate on anything. I found out later that I had taken one too many painkillers and that I was reacting to it. I started getting a fever as well. Just keeping my eyes open was painful. At two o’clock, I entered the examination room with my two advisors. Inside, two examiners were already seated. I don’t remember their names but one was an older woman, the other a man in his mid-thirties. “I have more experience than you,” said the woman to the man, “so I’ll take the lead on this if you don’t mind.” He didn’t, so they proceeded. One of the first questions to me was from the woman, who asked, “Are you feeling well?” Throughout the viva, she asked variants of this question, such as, “do you feel that you can continue? Should we reschedule?” I pressed on. The viva was unlike anything I had expected. Right at the beginning, the senior examiner said, “it’s clear this material is original and that you did it yourself, so we can dispense with all questions designed to determine originality, etcetera.” She then opened her copy of my viva, which was filled with what looked like hundreds of colorful tabs. Over the next four hours, she went through each note methodically, asking questions about my meaning, stating that this or that could be more clear, and then finally admonishing me that my finished thesis would lie permanently in the King’s library collection of student theses. For that reason it had to be perfect. I was given six months to make the required changes. As soon as that was announced, my supervisors broke out some champagne to celebrate. I don’t drink alcohol and had a blinding headache. On top of that, I didn’t understand what they were celebrating. As far as I could tell, I hadn’t passed the viva. I begged off on the celebration, may even have forgotten to shake everyone’s hand, and quickly made my exit. The next day, I was back at my doctor, getting an ultrasound of my digestive system. I was given a clean bill of health apart from the hernia, told that my pain killers were responsible for the pain experienced in London, and sent on my way. I spent the next several months carefully going through every note. I fixed everything I could think of, read it again, and fixed even more. The changes were not minor. My examiner had pointed out flaws in the argument that required a considerable amount of new reading of the relevant literature. I may have added as many as fifty new citations after going through a couple hundred new papers. Last, I had my daughter read it through. She’s rather clever as an editor, so I trusted her to spot any stylistic problems that interfered with the readability of the thesis. She spotted several dozen of these. Some required rewriting a paragraph, others required rewriting a couple of pages. I doubt I would have spotted these on my own. To her credit, she was the first person outside my supervisors or examiners who had read the thesis. I suspect she is only the second person to have read the full thesis after my senior viva examiner. My supervisors read the portions they had to read for feedback, and no one else who had requested a look had read any of it. I then submitted the thesis and it was approved. It had only taken about eight years in total. That said, a couple years’ of that time was spent waiting for feedback after being admonished not to write anything new until the feedback was given. Finally, I had the doctorate! My publisher then paid me an advance to publish the thesis as a book, and they did, just a few months later. Unfortunately, the acknowledgements page of the thesis was stripped away for the book because it had information specific to King’s that was not relevant to the thesis as a book. I didn’t notice that my thanks to my supervisors was at the bottom of the now missing page and submitted it to my publisher thinking that my supervisors were duly acknowledged. About a year later, I discovered that my supervisors hadn’t been thanked in the acknowledgements of the book when one of them said there were some hurt feelings about that. Unfortunately there was nothing to be done at that point. The book had been out for a year by then and there was no chance of a recall or errata. Meanwhile, the fact that I have a doctorate has only been “used” on one paper published a few months after the doctorate was awarded in 2018. In the paper, I am listed for the first time as “Andrew Paquette, PhD”.

In the UK its a little different or it was in the 90’s. It was standard practice to give a thesis defense, and I was unsurprisingly nervous as hell. I had driven up to my parents from Cornwall (8 hour drive) and dropped off my wife and very young children. the final 21/2 hrs from there to the uni I was on my own. I was terrified that I was going to miss the thing but I made it a few hours early. I stood outside the appointed room for a while and was called in. Facing me was the examiner and my supervisor, and to my left was Dr Platt the Uni internal examiner. You just get grilled on your thesis and have to explain/defend it all with no props. I had been told prior to this to be less animated with my hands because I tend to be very expressive discussing mechanisms. So I remember sitting down and gathering my thoughts and deliberately placing my fingers on the edge of the desk. I have very little recollection of my thesis defense - all 31/2 hours of it and then suddenly I was asked to leave the room and handed a pen and a piece of paper, and was told to fill it in. I went outside and stood in the corridor and read the first line of the form. it said “This form should be type written” You get the idea about just how fried I was by the process because I stood and looking at the pen and then at the form and back again over and over while my swirling brain tried to work out how the hell I was supposed to type write the form with a pen. Some time later My supervisor cam out and asked me to return and immediately turned his back. My heart fell and I followed him back into the room. Now I had been told before this by some of the other PhD’s that your thesis draft would be on the table in front of you. If it is the correct way up facing you its accepted, correct way up facing your examiner its minor rewrites. If its face down but facing your examiner its major rewrites, and if it was face down facing you it was rejected. With this zooming around in my head I went and took my seat . My draft thesis was sideways on to both myself and examiner. What the hell did that mean? While not exactly paying attention to what was being said while I figured out what was going on with the book on the desk in front of me, everyone stood up so I joined them. Suddenly my examiner leaned forwards and extended his hand for a handshake. I reciprocated while he uttered the immortal words “congratulations Dr Hywel-Evans”. I was then asked to surrender my car keys, which I did dazed by it all. I was asked to use a phone to contact my family while the tied up the paper work. Suddenly the staff of the department then appeared and whisked me off to the pub for a meal and sugary non alcoholic drinks. they would not give me my car keys back until I had stopped shaking and my supervisor had joined us for a celebration. I had been lifted up into the ranks of the chemistry department as an equal. Finally I got to get home where a glass of bubbly was waiting for me, and my wife asked slightly miffed, why I had been so low on the phone, as it had worried her to death. The thing is, to this day I swear that I tried really hard to be excited when I rang her.

Let’s start on the morning of. My defence was scheduled for 10 o’clock in the morning. I’d already picked up our tailcoats, white bow ties, and so on, the day before, and I’d arranged for my paranymphs to meet me at my home at 8:30. I live a short walk from the old university building, and they live in other cities, so this was the easiest way to do it. I get up early, have a shower, shave, make my usual strong morning coffee and have a spot of breakfast. And then, well, I wait. Pacing up and down my tiny flat in my dressing gown. Of course my paranymphs were late, but only by a few minutes. Well within the planned safety margin, but still nerve-wracking enough. Once the guys have arrived, we don our tails. While changing, one my paranymphs gets a phone call. Apparently he somehow managed to lock his wife into their flat in The Hague. Not a great look, but thankfully not my problem. We set out to the university. It’s sunny, but we take our umbrellas. Just in case. Get there, with plenty of time to spare. Take off our overcoats, post a selfie to Twitter, go upstairs. We meet the beadle and the acting rector magnificus, who is, of course, already wearing his professor’s cap and gown. Mill around for a bit, greet the first guests (including my parents, aunt and uncle, and cousin, who have flown in for the event). Turns out there’s a problem with the trains from Rotterdam that morning. Ah. Oh dear. Thank god my paranymph got into town before the problems started (that would have been awkward), but my photographer is also coming from Delft. By train. Luckily, he manages to rent a car, but it’s not the time of day to take a chance on traffic. As if there wasn’t enough suspense. ~9:58. The photographer arrives. In the nick of time. Now I can relax. Ladies and gentlemen, please rise for the committee!For some reason, I was completely taken aback by these words. I knew what was going to happen. I knew when it was going to happen. I knew what time it was. Still, I was surprised. Well, here we go. 45 minutes of questions. Hora est! Brief respite. Committee comes back, degree is granted in the traditional fashion. As per. 11 o’clock, the deed is done, but the day has only just begun. The next order of business is, of course, the reception. Many people shaking my hand. Some polite conversation, some group photos, some wine. My parents get to meet my supervisor. Some people who had been stuck on the train from Rotterdam for an hour actually turn up. The reception winds down around midday, so most people head to work while my paranymphs, my family and I make plans for lunch. I head home with my paranymphs, where we change into street clothes. On our way into the old town centre, we drop off our tails at the costume shop. Nice Dutch lunch en famille near the medieval canals. At this point, I am knackered. I go home to have a nap. On the way, I stop by the post office to pick up a parcel. They don’t have it. It later turns out to have been lost in the system. A few metres before my front door, I get a phone call from a company I’d interviewed at the previous week. Turns out they went with a different candidate. Who cares. I need some sleep. After all, I was going to need my energy later. There was still a dinner with family, paranymphs and professors planned for that evening, followed by a party until late into the night. (Well, not that late. Most of the guests had to work in the morning)

10AM: Defense 12PM: Leave seminar hall with advisor and remaining donuts/coffee (pass). Seven years to a complete stop in two hours. ‘WTF moment’. 12:20PM: get back to lab. A good many ‘thumbs up’. Someone had enough balls to ask “great, so what’s next?” 12:20–2PM: pace around the lab and floor in my business attire, with a not-so-typical grin on my face. Text family. The news reaches extended family so I am entertaining texts and phone calls off/on for the rest of the day. 2PM: lab group ‘party’ on our floor. Food and cake, but no booze since “it was a bit too early in the day”. I was OK with that, for now. ~3:30PM: Party over, clean up. ~3:45PM: Still in my business attire, leave lab with my one and only undergrad lab assistant to grab Starbucks tea and chill out at a local park. Talk about Life and my “real opinions” on grad school. ~4:30PM: Part ways with undergrad. Head back to lab. Respond to a few congratulatory emails from colleagues. ~5PM: Set up celebration dinner with my sister (only local family member) for later in the evening. ~5:15PM: Start filling out “termination” paperwork for grad school. Because, yeah, I was done and it was getting done real fast. 6PM: Go home. Grin still on face. 6:15PM: Power nap. ~7:30PM: Hop into my sis’s Uber, continue to dinner. ~8PM: Dinner + booze ~10PM: Part ways with sis. Walk home. ~10:45PM: Get comfortable. Answer a few more texts. Make a snack. Netflix. ~12AM: Bed. Sleep like a baby. (coupled with the anxiety, last minute b.s., and poor sleep leading up to D-day, I was dead). 3-Days later: Take short Train trip to meet up with parents for the weekend. Have fun. 7 Days later: Back to lab. Paperwork. What’s next, indeed.

In Japan they call them PhD defenses. Total of three (03) defense — predefence, public defence, and final defense. Predefence is done sometime when your supervisor thinks you have accumulated enough research output (for example papers in IEEE journals, etc.). This is evinced by an acceptance letter for your article in that particular journal. Then you have an approval to go for public and final defense. Owkey. My story. _______ The public defense was scheduled for 19th July 2017. There were two of us from my lab each doing his defense alone. It was afternoon. The room was packed — fellow students, industry personnel, professors, and other invitees from other universities. My presentation took 25 minutes of the one hour alloted. I dunno why, but I have a weakness of preparing super short presentations. The questions were educative. The comments were helpful. But I had to have solid answers for those comments/questions during the final defense. The final defense was on 20th July 2020. Now this was a terrifying day. I had prepared all answers as asked in the public defense. Also, my presentation now was much ripe. It contained all the achievements — papers published, short CV, short carrier plan, and academic history. I used about 55 minutes of the alloted 1 hour and then REALLY hard questions began. I was in the GRILL for almost one hour. Then, my supervisor asked me to wait outside so they decide if I was worth a PhD. During the waiting they also grilled my colleague from yesterday. Then he came out. We chatted and I was more nervous. We waited for the committee to finish. After some time, they decided to tell us to go to the lab and wait there, I tried to be cheerful to no avail. Then about one hour passed. I became even more nervous. At last, my supervisor came. And he called out to me and my colleague. I approached him and stood close by. He said. Congratulations Dr. Aviti. He shook my hand. He then said to my colleague. Congratulatios Dr. XYZ. We were super joyous. Our lab colleagues then congratulated us. A party was prepared that evening — order of our supervisor. We celebrated and got wasted. I got super drunk. I remember to have talked a lot to my supervisor, lab colleagues and other well wishers. I was very much jubilant. Thereafter, my African friends took me to another party at family food joint (like KFC, I forgot the name.) There then another eating and drinking bout started. At least this is what I remember.

It was over a half century ago. I don’t remember exactly what I did immediately afterward. I was already teaching at a nearby college of science and engineering - so I probably had a lecture to prepare for the following day. The thesis defense itself was rather strange. It had been six months since I had completed my research and submitted the paper for publication. I had begun my college teaching, while spending nights finishing up the thesis itself and preparing for the defense. Of the three defense committee members, my principle research advisor (who was the department chair), a secondary advisor, and a third professor, nearly all the questions were being asked by only the secondary advisor - grilling me on research by a post-doc that had been going on during that last six months, which I was not privy to. It was his last opportunity to have any authority over me. After an hour and a half, or so, of that, my principle advisor just said, “Well, his research paper has been accepted for publication, I think we can all agree that he has successfully defended his work.” And that was it. I walked out of that meeting thinking, “Wow, that was anticlimactic.” And there was an enormous sense of relief. But, frankly, I don’t remember what I did next. I’m sure I called my fiance with the news, I probably called my parents - although they probably wouldn’t have understood what was meant by a thesis defense. There was still some paperwork to file, and delivering copies of my signed dissertation to the graduate division for inclusion in the library. And, oh yeah, a lecture to prepare for the following morning at the nearby college of science and engineering.

My defense was over at 2 pm on a Friday. I was due to start teaching as a faculty member (Research Assistant Professor) starting the next Monday. So immediately after defending, I had to go file some papers with human resources at the university. (Nothing degree related, just basic stuff like selecting health insurance and retirement options.) Then I went to my favorite Italian restaurant for dinner by myself at 3:30. Then I went home and slept, got up Saturday morning, and put the finishing touches on the syllabus(i) for the courses I was teaching. Here is a defense tip: At some universities - generally universities dominated by their humanity programs - defenses are heavily regulated with a fixed length. At other institutions - like mine - the only criteria was that the defense by published and a majority of the committee had to be physically present. It could last for six hours if the committee so chose. When I scheduled my defense, one of the committee members said, “O.K. Friday at 12 will be fine…. but I have an important meeting with the Dean at 3 pm…” I had a huge grin on my face, and said “wonderful.” If your university does not have a fixed requirement for the length of a defense, make sure you schedule it for a day and time where at least one committee member has another, later, appointment that they cannot miss. This will force the defense to a quick close. In my case, it wasn’t as if I would have been grilled for hours, it was just that we would have stayed there for hours talking about our research and gossiping about university politics. Schedule your defense very carefully.

I left the room where my defense was held and the faculty remained. I headed down the hall to what was effectively the “graduate student lounge” and chatted with my peers while I waited for them to discuss… I don’t know how long that was, but not too long before the department admin called me back in. There were lots of hand-shakes and exchanging of pleasantries, lots of relief from me, advisor was very happy. I called my fiancée who was in another department and shared the good news and she hurried over. We all headed downstairs for a little celebratory fruit cheese-and-crackers and drinks with the other grad students. We hung out a good long while and I chatted with my advisor quite a bit. I had a couple of pieces of paperwork I had to sign off on, and then a bunch of us went out for dinner. The few days after that I spent doing some additional dotting of i’s and crossing of t’s to meet that various remaining paperwork requirements of the university, but then I resume work on another project that my thesis advisor and I were working on (basically, taking a bit of my thesis work and marking part of it a commercial product). The market was too niche to be a big commercial product, but we ended up doing a fair share of consulting for a while. I left about 18 months later for family reasons (my mother, who lived out of state, was having a health crisis that required family support).

I’m just a MSc, but I work in a research department that has hosted a whole lot of PhD students, and I’ve been part of most of the process a number of times. The routine at the University of Oslo, Faculty of medicine, is something like this: A few days ahead, you get a subject for your trial lecture; typically something suited for a 45 min presentation to a room of master students, and in the general field of your thesis. From about 10:15 you present this trial lecture. This is a trial of your ability to present and teach: UiO likes to emphasis how the PhD qualifies you to lecture at the University if you should so desire. I’ve never heard about anyone failing; by the time you get this far everyone seems able to scrape together a powerpoint presentation and talk about it. You then get a lunch break before your defense, which is typically held at 12:15 the same place as the trial lecture. It starts with the dean of the faculty (or a deputy) presenting the candidate, title of the thesis, the opponents, and the evaluation of the trial lecture (since passing that is technically a requirement). You then present your thesis, the first and then second opponent asks you questions and discusses your thesis and more general themes with you, there’s a window for questions from the audience, and then the candidate and audience leave for the lounge for sparkly wine and biscuits. After some minutes the opponents+dean appear and declare that you passed. Mingling happens, and then you go home to relax a bit. Later in the evening, there’s always a dinner, for the candidate (now PhD), opponents, head of committee, advisors, and usually a number of colleagues, family and friends, with a number of speeches. It usually lasts until people remember they have work the next morning, unless you’ve managed to arrange to have your defense on a Friday.

I had a long desire to do a PhD. I had made my email id with dr prefix when I was in undergrad. At that time I didn’t know from where I will do it but I was sure I will do PhD. It was more of emotion then rather than passion. But nevertheless research as a process is the best experience I feel I will ever have. Here is the story of my D-Day: My PhD thesis defence was scheduled at 9.30 am. By 10.45 a.m. I was done with presentation and Q&A. My external who had flown to Bangalore from IIT Ropar said he was satisfied with Q&A. Thesis reports from externals (one from within India and one from abroad) had already arrived long back. My External examiner verified whether I had included all the suggestions asked in report and had given clarifications of queries in the updated version of the thesis. He then approved and finally recommended me for award of the degree. Rest of the day passed in office work getting no dues etc. One of the best compliment of my life I had got when he told me that he had thoroughly enjoyed reading my thesis. I was more than happy. Nowadays nobody have so much time and excitement to read others work in full detail and if my work can generate interest even to one researcher, it gives me immense sense of fulfilment. This complement will remain with me throughout my life. He further suggested me to make my code modules open source which he feels can be great contribution. All stressed nerves connecting brain and gut loosened up. I almost sink with feeling that its a closure of a fun and excitement mixed struggle. It’s a moment that I can only experience. Imagine you get your name as soon as you are born but just to add a small two letter prefix it takes close to half of your life and whose worth you will be never explain to others and may be never to yourselves too. Only in the evening I feel fully relaxed and since it was also Friday evening, I went out with my lab-mates and oh gosh what a party it was. Being an introvert, I have never danced in my life and that day I danced my heart out. I won’t say I don’t like being addressed as Dr. though it’s not always desirable but nevertheless its always an incredible feeling to be part of top 1% of the world (academically).

“I think Samvit (my official name) has answered all questions thrown at him by the external reviewers, myself, and the audience,” said Prof. Shivshankar from the Indian Institute of Science. “I also feel that this thesis contains some inspiring and potentially groundbreaking work in the field of materials synthesis for commercial applications and thus, let’s conclude today’s session by congratulating Samvit Menon on successfully defending his thesis. Congratulations, Dr. Menon” And then he got up from his seat, walked over to me and shook my hand. “Well done, Dr. Menon. You should be proud of your achievement,” he said, patting me on my back.  Unfortunately, I don’t have a better picture! Ah, well, more than anything, I was just happy that this was all over. I was looking forward to spending some time catching my breath since it had been an exhausting last few months. Soon after this, everyone from my department came up to congratulate me, including my HoD, even though we’ve had our history (especially since I was dating his student) and spilled a lot of bad blood in the process.  Here’s everyone welcoming the new “doctor” on the block!! These are my friends, juniors and master’s thesis students who I was supervising at the time!  Ummm, this is the mandatory “Mallu-Gang” group photo! Even though I’m half Keralite, none of the other Keralites in our department felt I was one of them until that day! Well, yeah, sure, you can have a piece of me now! That’s my girlfriend looking on as if to tell me, “you frikkin’ deserter!”  Here’s she saying, “yea, you guys suck at taking selfies! Allow me!” After all this drama, there was a lovely tea party for everyone who had come there. Tea, biscuits, saavige baath (it’s a traditional Kannadiga savoury made out of vermicelli. God, I miss Kannadiga food!) and samosas. And to make things even better, it was served by the cafeteria lady who we were all extremely fond of. “Oh, it’s your group!” she exclaimed when she saw us, the regular tea-time gang! “Yes,” we smiled. “It’s us, indeed!” “Our man here just finished his PhD,” Krishna, my friend and my master’s thesis student said. “He is now Dr. Samvit Menon.” “Ooooh! Congratulations,” she said. “This is fantastic.” “Thank you,” I said, blushing profusely. I wasn’t used to this kind of attention. “Enjoy your tea!” Just then my phone buzzed. You’ve got mail! I opened my mail. “Thank you for your positive application as a postdoctoral researcher to our group. We would be delighted to have you here. Your offer letter would be sent to you in three days time.” Whoa!! “Hey mister… I mean, doctor,” Vanessa, my girlfriend said, teasing me while poking my belly, “we all have phones, you know!” “I uhhh— I just got an offer from South Africa,” I said, my heart threatening to burst out of my chest.” “What!” everyone yelled. “Talk about timing!” Deepak, my junior, said. “It’s a double dhamaka today! A double whammy! Congrats again!” So, I rushed to my thesis advisor and was about to give him the good news when my phone buzzed again. You’ve got mail. Again. “I was extremely happy with the discussion we had the other day and I do feel with your skills and our lab’s objectives, you would be a perfect fit for our group. I have spoken to our Dean and we are in the process of opening up a position for you. You will receive an offer letter within this week, or latest, by the next. I look forward to having you here.” No. Bloody. Way! “Ummm, sir, I uhh.. j-just got two postdoc offers within ten minutes of each other!” I said, extremely breathless. This was unbelievable. “That’s fantastic,” he said, slapping me on my back. “Wait, there’s one person I want you to stick it to! Wait right here!” And then he meandered through and disappeared into the crowd, only to reappear two minutes later with our department head. “Haan, Samvit, kya hai? What is it? Suresh says there’s something you want to tell me,” he said, trying to sound authoritative. I looked at my thesis advisor. He winked, “go ahead and tell him.” “S-sir,” I stammered. “I just got two postdoc offers.” “What? Right now?” “Yes, sir.” “When did you apply?” “Some time back,” I was purposely being vague as my confidence began rising. “Where are they from? India?” “Haha! No, sir!” I replied, letting out a stifled chuckle. And this time, I smiled. All those people who tried to make my life hell can go suck it! “One’s from South Africa and the other is from Ireland.” “Whoa!” he gasped. “Tu sach bol raha hai? You telling the truth?” He said in a thick Malayalee accent. “Yup!” I showed him the mails. He gaped at me and my thesis advisor. “Sahi hai. That’s good. So, have you decided which one you’re gonna pick?” “Not yet. I have time!” “Go to Ireland! It’s in Europe,” he said. “You’ll have a better life there.” “We’ll see,” I said, as I left both of them to join my friends. That evening, I had invited a select few people home for some drinks and dinner. I had bought the bottle of sparkling rose on a recent trip to Sri Lanka and a friend of mine had got me the Paddy’s from Ireland, both of which I had kept patiently to opened only after my defense.  A few days later, I arranged a lunch for the department, and later, my thesis advisor arranged a dinner for me and some of the professors he and I were close with and that was that! Two months later, I joined my current university in South Africa as a postdoc.

After I’ve presented my work and answered questions from examiners, the chairperson of the defense which was my boss said, OK, it is now time for all of you to leave and leave the committee members in the room to come to a decision. So me and the rest of the crowd stepped outside of the room. Here I am, in Austria, 34 thousands miles away from home (Malaysia) pursuing a deferred dream. I had invited a small community of friends and we chatted. Some people from the campus which was interested in the subject also came, said good job, and left to do their things for the day. Their took rather long time in the room, before my boss and the rest of the committee emerged. My boss said, congratulations, you have now passed with a grade of sehr gut. I said thank you. And other people congratulate me. My boss says if all of you please join us, let’s go upstairs to the kitchen for some celebration. I stayed back a little bit so that my Malaysian friends could take photos, so that they could leave for the day. I don’t remember much even though it was just 3 years ago. I think for the rest of the day I worked on the paper work and push it up to the university people. Maybe at the end of the day I go back to my empty shared apartment. Maybe I cook rice (as an Asian I have to eat rice every so often to maintain sanity). Maybe briani rice with chicken since that’s the most lavish dish I can cook by myself. Perhaps in the evening I took the tram around the city and enjoy the beautiful Vienna. As I typed this I cried a little. It has been a spiritual journey. There was sadness and disappointment along the way, yet filled with love and adventure. I think I did an OK PhD. Yeah. I’ve achieved my life time dreams…

After my Ph.D thesis defense— immediately after, or way into the future? Anyway, I’ll answer both. My Ph.D defense seminar was scheduled on July 20, 2017, at 1130 hrs IST in the Electrical Engineering Department, IIT Bombay. The seminar was attended not just by my thesis advisor, doctoral thesis committee, and the external examiner, but also almost 40 of my friends, whose support was invaluable to me! As planned, my seminar lasted a little over an hour, with me blabbing for about 45 minutes, followed by discussions. I was asked various technical questions regarding novelty angles, working principles, utility of my research outcome, and more. Finally, the external examiner asked me, ‘so what’s next?’ I gave an enigmatic smile and said, ‘academia, ultimately. Sooner or later.’ By around 1245 hrs, we were nearly done. I posed for a photograph with my advisor, committee professors, and examiners, and after that, my advisor took us (me and some of our lab research group members) out for lunch to celebrate. Post lunch, I decided to go home to celebrate with my family. I bought a bottle of wine and opened it with my parents, who took a customary sip to toast my success before disposing the bottle (we aren’t drinkers, TBH). The next couple of days were hectic— I had to vacate my hostel room. It was an emotional time. I had spent nearly six years in that room. It took me multiple trips back and forth, to decide what I wanted to keep, what I wanted to dispose, and what I wanted to donate to charity. On 21 July (the very next day after my defense), I joined IIT Bombay as a Research Associate, where I continued my research for a few months, while applying for academic positions. I was invited to teach electronic circuit simulators to sophomores at IIT Goa and IIT Dharwad, which I did during July—August 2017. I was also invited to give faculty seminars at IIT Goa, Roorkee, and Gandhinagar. In November 2017, I travelled to Singapore to present our research at a symposium. The trip was funded by the Department of Science and Technology (DST), Govt. of India. In December 2017, I received an invitation to deliver a faculty seminar at IIT Bhubaneswar. I travelled to Bhubaneswar where I interacted with the faculty through my research seminar, following which I was scheduled to appear for a selection interview. I was grilled in that interview by a committee of 8 people for 90 minutes, and ten days later, I received the offer. I finally had a job in academia. Finally, on 4 January 2018, I bade goodbye to IIT Bombay, and the city of Mumbai, and am a faculty member at IIT Bhubaneswar ever since.

This can be considered as my first “formal” Quora answer. I did my remote thesis defense three weeks ago. Before moving on to my full-time job in a month, it was supposed to be a casual time that I could eventually wake up slightly later and go to bed slightly earlier than my stressful time in thesis/slides preparation. I had two non-academic books in my mind for a long time and finally get a big chunk of time to read them. I had a cup of coffee beside me every day but no caffeine needed. Then, not even after a week-long peaceful time, I received a call on a Thursday afternoon from the company that I am joining and was told that my group, unfortunately, shut down. As an outcome, my offer would be rescinded if no internal transfer came out. I did not have much time to be indulged in this sad moment but began my job searching process right away. As you might expect, I put down my non-academic books and re-picked up the interview preparation materials from my bookshelf. The cup beside me is no longer decaf anymore. To be honest, I was popular in the market about a year ago where almost all companies gave me interviews right away after my applications, but the job market becomes pretty inelastic due to the current pandemic. Anyways, the experience of mine is unique and I wish no one else would have it in her/his entire life. What I can do is to work hard and hope for the best. What makes me feel less upset nowadays? Obtained my Ph.D.

This goes way back to November 2007. I was TAing Applied Math in the last semester that I defended my dissertation in and helping out a co-advisor as a half RA with some theoretical work. After a successful late evening defense and the customary congratulations, I called up family in India and then took friends out to a restaurant to celebrate. I already had a faculty offer in writing from IIT Kanpur to teach and research there a couple of months ahead of the defense [and positive feelers from a couple of other old IITs too] and I told my research colleagues and friends after the defense that that would be what I would take up.
