However, I still wanted to close my TA and theoretical obligations and had a time of a 45 days to finalize things. Three days from the defense, I interviewed over phone with a researcher from a new Max-Planck institute for a postdoctoral scientist position and that transitioned into an offer. I was invited by another US university for a faculty seminar presentation in January 2008. I wanted to evaluate all these before finalizing. Then four days after the defense, a patent law firm in the US inquired about my availability in the market. I flew to their location in December and, by early January 2008, had another offer. Fred Frith (w/ Evelyn Glennie) was to do two shows at my university on two different days after all my obligations were completed and my Jan (18 I think!) faculty presentation in the US ended. Although I wasn’t convinced by the IIT offer and the US university, I had a funny enough perspective to stay at the (small) city of my university long enough to attend the shows haha. And in December 2007, I had fulfilled a long held travel related desire. Finally, I took up the patent law firm offer in the US. Now, with the benefits of hindsight, I would’ve stuck to academia if I were to travel back in time.

I did my master’s in Psychology in 2 years after my engineering degree and three years in aerospace. My first publication with my mentor after my first year was a monograph of seven experiments published in the primary journal in my discipline. After several publications, I then did my dissertation and obtained my PhD in nine months. My research and publications during my graduate training were in one focused area which explains how I was able to go from engineering to PhD in psychology in less than 3 years. My master’s defense took 8 hours owing to long and prolonged arguments between my mentor and a member of the dissertation committee. Everyone sat back (including myself) and watched the argument. My dissertation defense took 45 minutes. I had already secured a two-year postdoctoral fellowship at a medical school that could begin at any time after my PhD. So, after my doctoral defense, I went to my office to pack up. Said goodbye and thank you to my mentor, fellow graduate students, and departmental support staff. I went home to have a nice dinner with my wife and children. The next day I picked up a rental UHaul trailer, packed it, and began the 2-day drive to begin my postdoc.

I defended my dissertation in January of 1976 at Columbia University. No one was in the room except for the committee and me. No others were invited, and online viewership was still decades away from being invented! I waited outside until they were done, and it was a great feeling when my advisor came out and said, “Congratulations Dr. Sethna!” For more details, please see Beheruz N Sethna's answer to How is it possible to finish a PhD in less than five years? I walked the few blocks back to my apartment on Broadway, carrying two large bags of hard copies of all my outputs (there was no such thing as a laptop at that time) and my arms were a lot longer when I reached my apartment than when I started! I gave my wife the great news. We made phone calls to my parents and hers who were in India, and to a few relatives of hers who lived in the US, and then went out for a pleasant but inexpensive meal. When I say, “a” meal, that’s what I mean. We were broke so, on the very rare occasions we went out to a nice restaurant, we would order one meal. She is a vegetarian and would eat the veggies and bread, and I would eat the meat and rice!

Lived together. My wife enrolled for her Phd in Jan,2013. in Germany. As a married couple, with me being a non science/PhD person, trust me that its not an easy ride. My German visa came through in Nov,2013 and I landed in Germany in Jan,2014. Since then, this was our timeline: Jan, 2013 to Jan, 2014 : She was in Heidelberg, Germany; I was in Bangalore, India,Jan,2014 to June, 2014 : We lived together in Heidelberg, Germany since I was looking for a job,July,2014 to March, 2015 : Due to a job offer, I moved to Berlin and she was still in Heidelberg,Apr,2015 to Okt, 2015 : I moved to Munich to work with Amazon, and she was in Heidelberg,Nov,2015 to Dec, 2016 : I moved back to Berlin after leaving Amazon, and her lab moved to Munich,Her Phd defense was on 9th Dec, 2016. Her PhD was done, but wait….. Jan 2017 to Sept, 2017 - Her first job was in a small German city, Gottingen. I was still in Berlin.Finally in Sept, 2017 she was able to get a job offer with which she moved to Berlin. Sept, 2017 - to date : happy and thankful to be living together finally. For those who might be curious, due to my finance profile and lack of German language skills, jobs were only possible in big cities. Heidelberg is a student city, with focus on life sciences. Thankfully, I was able to travel every weekend to meet my wife. She could not travel so frequently as her PhD required lab experiments on weekends too, due to incubation times (I hope I used this term properly.. if not, sorry). While travelling every weekend is expensive and takes a physical toll, German tax laws are amazing. As a married couple, we were living in different cities due to professional reasons. In such a case, all of that travel expenses can be claimed in the yearly tax returns. If you want to know more about living and working in Germany, then follow Quora Spaces : CDG - Career Development

First thing was go to my supervisor and tell him I had minor corrections only. After that, I phoned my dad and then my mum (they’re divorced) to tell them. Then went home and relaxed for the evening. I think I did go out with some friends for a couple of drinks but spent most of the evening by myself. In the longer term, I sought out some postdocs and submitted applications but got nowhere with them, not even securing an interview for one that pretty much described me. I also went to a temping agency and made myself available for work. Began next week at the local hospital to do admin work for an online course there which I did for about 5 months. Pay wasn’t great but okay, work was okay, colleagues were good but the main thing was it was honest work. It did, however, lead directly to a postdoc fellowship that was my life’s most enjoyable work situation. I investigated the usability of online learning services for postgraduate medical students for 3 years and also spent time investigating educational validity which was a real challenge, interesting and fun.

On the day of my defense Waited outside the room at the University for the examiner and my advisor to finish formalities. Texted my family that I was done with the final presentation of my PhD work. Examiner and advisor said “Congratulations, Dr. Kanchana!” (the first time you hear it, its the sweetest thing). Took them out for lunch along with my SO. Returned home, did a hop, skip, and jump (who am I kidding- did a lot of jumping around) to just express my happiness! Called my entire family over the next few hours. In the week after my defense Distributed sweets (mithai) to the entire institute where I did my PhD and to all the neighbors. Planned on having a party for everyone in the lab A month after my defense Attended the convocation ceremony at the University and got the honor to march in the academic procession. My entire family got to attend this ceremony and it was also telecasted on local TV channels. Threw a party for my lab people and had good fun :-)  Apart from all this, once I knew a reviewer had been assigned, I applied for post-doc positions, gave interviews and in general was trying to figure out the proverbial “what next?”. No one knows it or gets it the moment they graduate. My advice: bask in the glory of being awarded the ‘degree of a lifetime’ (no one says much about it once you are beyond this stage and its only been eight months since I got mine :-D)

Let me re-called my memory again about the moment after did my thesis defense. I did my thesis defense on February,13th this year.First thing that I did was saying thank you to all reviewers and my supervisor. Then took pictures with them. After that, I prepared some documents to be submitted to university. The day afterthat, I decided to just stay at home cause Covid19 starting to spread in Japan. I expected this virus will be affected many people, and my expectations was correct. So What I was doing during staying at home? Learning and preparing for Job interview.

As best I can remember 28 years later… I waited outside the room where my defense was held. During that time, I spoke with friends who attended the proceedings. After a few minutes, my advisor emerged, shook my hand and said “Congratulations, Dr. Kurtzman.” We had a short conversation. I drove home, told my wife I passed, and then probably opened a bottle of wine. The next few weeks were spent making minor edits on the thesis and making sure the document got through the formatting requirements of the university library. While I was working through that administrivia, I started looking for employment.

2020 has been a strange year because of Covid-19. I defended my PhD thesis on July 28, 2020. When I had started my PhD in 2015, little did I know that I would be defending my thesis in an empty room all by myself. Even my PhD advisor would not be there. Here I am defending my PhD in an empty room.  Typically an invite to all students from the department would go to attend someone’s PhD thesis. After the defense, everyone would come and congratulate the person on his/her special day. But for me, that particular day, there was only one person in the entire building and he congratulated me maintaining social distance. :D I went home and then had a party with my roommates that evening celebrating the completion of my PhD. An awesome thing happened though because of all of this. My family from India could attend my PhD defense because it was held on Zoom. Else, they would have just waited for my Whatsapp message to say I have successfully defended. I am extremely happy that I could share that moment with my entire family even if they were miles apart from me. I guess every dark cloud has a silver lining.

14:00–16:00 Thesis defense (in Wien at the Faculty) 16:00–17:30 Dinner with the committee in a nice little restaurant in Wien downtown (head of faculty, head of department, professors of the committe and the opponent – unfortunately my supervisor could not be present due to medical conditions) 18:00 A little ceremony when I was officially conferred the doctor's degree and the documents were handed over to me (the key reason is that I didn't want to wait until July, the official ceremony – and I was offered this opportunity, as my defense was in November) 19:xx I catched the Wien-Budapest train and travelled home Career wise: nothing. I have submitted my papers to HR so that my doctoral title is shown in the system. Otherwise nothing happened as I am working as a strategy manager and I made a phd in old testament theology.

My thesis defence was in the morning. The day beforehand I had driven across the UK, via London to pick up my girlfriend, to Swansea in Wales. Traffic was a nightmare so we didn’t get into Swansea until very late. So I got up in the morning early to head over to defence. After my defence I sat in the teacher’s lounge with my advisor, my girlfriend, and a few fellow Ph.D.s who were floating around waiting for the news. I was absolutely bricking myself, as I was unsure if it had gone well enough. I mostly felt sick, and I hadn’t eaten anything real or morning so that was not helping. Then the news came that I had passed, my supervisor showed up with champagne, more students arrived, as well as a few profs. We drank, we chatted, we celebrated that I had done it. Then, slightly tipsy my girlfriend and I wandered into my old haunts to find some food to try and sober us up. Sobered up we went back to my friend’s house, where we were staying, and had a nap and finished sobering up. In the evening we went to a restaurant with my old Uni friends who still live in the area, and had a catch up and celebrated. Once I got home to Austria I had to begin making corrections, but the 36 hours after finishing were just chill celebration.

The other answers have a good description of what occurred right after the defense. I was congratulated, treated like equal by committee members, and so on. The moment I like to describe, however, was a very remarkable one. I remember being in my living room, after drinking some beer, a week or two after the defense. At that time, I had already done all the small text fixes proposed by the committee and had no more PhD assignments. The last two years were very intense, and I was almost absent from family life. Even at home, the small moments I truly stay with my daughter and wife were followed by a kind of guilt. After all, I should be writing, fixing code, doing experiments, etc. That day, as we say here in Brazil, “a ficha caiu”. Something like “the penny dropped” in the UK. I realized that the guilt went away. There was nothing to do except drink that beer and being with my family. That was the most delicious beer and moment in years. Guiltless.

I defended in March of 2020. The university hadn’t shut down yet, but it was close (I think it was literally the next day). Even still, I was only allowed to have my committee in the room and I had to present my talk over Zoom. Due to concerns over COVID, my family did not make the trip to visit, despite having planned on it literally weeks earlier. As social distancing was being enforced at the time, after I defended to my committee I went home. A little while afterwards I joined in on a Zoom call with others from the university to celebrate my defense, an event that is typically held in person with snacks and drinks (don’t worry, there was still wine). Still, it was nice talking to people and to my surprise a former student in the first year of his postdoc decided to drop in, something that couldn’t happen if it wasn’t digital so that was nice. I would have liked to go out with family and friends to a restaurant or bar, but COVID had closed everything down. So my wife and I prepared dinner, I have no idea what anymore, and the next day I set to work on the corrections my committee outlined for me.

For my university, PhD submission as well defence were critical. Upon submission your final thesis is reviewed and given back with major or minor correction plus some editing. In my university, the most stressful part is PhD submission as it carries a semester fees (~10K usd) penalty if u don't submit on time. Submission deadline: 3:00 PM Had not slept for the past 72 hours. Final edits under caffeine fuelled and sleep deprived situation:2:40 PM Thesis submission: 2:45 PM ONLINE CONFIRMATION : 2:56 (I think) Chat with prof about doing back up expt or potential correction: 3:30 Booked one way flight to india: 3:45PM for flight at 6:30PM Raced to airport and reached 4:45ish At Airport:airline didn't issue boarding pass as the third party had not sent them the information Booked another flight via a stop over, 11:00 PM flight and stopover for 5 hours for morning connecting flight. Finally met family with close to 85 hours of sleep depravation. Worth it!!!!! Defence was much more chilled out, did presentation for 45 mins and viva for 45 to 60 mins. Took the whole group for dinner for Indian spicy food.

After more than a half century, I have no memory of either defense at all. There were two thesis defenses, the Physics Departmental defense — which was the tough one, and the University defense, which was a formality. I was warned by fellow students that, for appearances during the defense, my thesis advisor might aggressively question me — but only on something he was confident that I knew the answer to. The only upset to my demeanor came when it was time to deposit my thesis in the university library. My PhD would be dated according to that act. I wanted my degree to be dated on April Fool’s Day, so having post-doc employment near campus, I held onto the thesis until April 1. I took the document into the library, but was told that I had misinterpreted instructions to have the pagination in pencil, rather than typed on each page. After explanation of my plan, the librarian agreed that my degree would be dated April 1, even if the document arrived a day or two later.

Immediately after the thesis defense, I had lunch with my wife in a Chinese restaurant. Then, around 6 hours later, I had dinner with the thesis board in another restaurant. Then life continued as usual. I continued with my job, and continued with my research.

Went out to dinner with my committee and a few friends, then spent a couple of weeks in Bisbee AZ and environs decompressing with an old friend from my undergrad days while she researched her novel. Photo credit: Bisbee: Hippie paradise with a historic flare - Arizona News

Went over to the Faculty Club with my advisor and the rest of my Defense Committee. My girlfriend joined us and after a few sedate rounds of drinks with the group the two of us headed off to dinner and drank far too much wine. My apartment had a fireplace so I built a fire and burned all the handwritten drafts of my thesis - crumpled them up and threw them in page by page.

Most Ph.D. defenses are not suspenseful affairs where the outcome is in doubt. That is, they’re not like the Academy Awards, where there is an emotional “I made it!” outburst when the defense is successful, which it usually is. So, in my case I certainly felt some relief at having it over, but it wasn’t an occasion for a big celebration. I did take my wife out to dinner that evening, more to thank her for being so understanding during the dissertation process.

I don’t recall. I think I drove home that night to Pittsburgh, about 2.5 hours away, so it wasn’t anything involving alcohol. I remember the defense only vaguely, relative to some other moments in my life that I remember in detail. It was the end; nice to achieve, but not enormously significant in itself for me. If it makes any sense, I knew once it was over that I was going to pass; before that, I felt a fair bit of anxiety, but I don’t think I could have been even marginally better prepared.
I took a post-defense selfie.  Or as I like to call it, a doc pic. This is me sitting in my old office. Eyes were red due to lack of sleep.

I was a teaching assistant for a second year lab course on Computer Architecture. Undergrad students run their assembly language programs on 68000 boards in the lab and debug them. Right after the thesis defense, I had to rush to the lab to do my TA work. I got a one year position as a research assistant professor before my thesis defense. The next day I went to a different office and worked on the papers that I was working on before the defense. The next term, I taught a course on Digital Communication to final year Electrical Engineers. A year later I moved to a government research lab and another year later to industry.

A2A Gave the biggest party / treat I have ever given at an upscale restaurant overlooking the iconic Marina Bay Sands in SingaporeGave a warm and cozy treat to family members in Chennai (India) at an upscale restaurant on its famous coastlineWent on an Europe tour after the degree got conferred (since I had a conference to attend there anyway!)You could do all that or just vanish from the world for a few days to calmness and serenity, whatever that means to you, and come back to real world when you are ready! It’s all up to you. No rules! Everyone has a style!

I did PhD from US. I was so exhausted and frustrated about my whole PhD experience, that I felt a BIG relief, instead of joy, when I got the confirmation that I passed my PhD defense. I enjoyed sleeping probably the most on that day because before that I used to have bad/horrific dreams about my adviser and/or project (which never gave me satisfying results) even while sleeping :(

Unlike others here, we don't do thesis defense in Australia, or at least we didn't eight years ago at my university. But we did receive grades (basically pass or fail) from external examiners. Once I got mine I sent an email to my family saying I passed and I think that was it. Soon after, I got married. So there was that. Puts life in perspective.

What do you mean, immediately after, or the next day, or with the rest of my life? Immediately after, I got a beer. By myself. It was very satisfying. That weekend my wife treated me to dinner at the Four Seasons. Next day, I went to work. It was already obvious by the time I was writing my dissertation that there were not going to be any real jobs in my field in academia, and by the time I defended I had already transitioned to Wall Street, so I simply went back to work. The rest of my life? See above.

In the US it is usually a dissertation at the end of a doctorate. The thesis is for the Master’s. After defense, order it bound. You may have yet to sit for an exam of several hours. Then file for graduation and order your robe and announcement cards, if you have not yet. We did have one occasion after everybody passed and their dissertation was published and bound when we all had a big meal together with our spouses and signed each other’s copies. I think there were 8 or 10 of us. It was the last time I’ve seen some of those people.

Mine was on a Friday June 17 at 1pm and it was a group of about 10 friends including my mother and my committee and one on the phone .
